ygData.msgSnippet: Hi, ... It should be easy enough for NEAT to find a solution I think. ... The realtime limit is unfortunate, but then the subtask of moving to the ball should

Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Advice for Bachelor level Final Project
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=294161626; y=vf-R1C1-auOfgT_sw8rTJEvhyrgwH22ANv52-1ioiUj4ThB8d3yF
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod

Hi,

On 09/01/2008, Faisal Abidi <fabidi@...> wrote:

> What we're trying to teach the networks is to get closer to the ball. robocup soccer server
> (rcss) allows our agents to have access to relative distance and angle (relative to the
> player's facing) of the ball.
> With these as the inputs we want the network to minimize the angle (0 means dead-on)
> and the distance. The closer the angle and distance to 0 the greater the fitness.

It should be easy enough for NEAT to find a solution I think.


> Currently, we're running the simulation in realtime (couldn't figure out a simple way to
> speed up game time on server end:S) with 10 players (the population) in the sim. Each is
> oblivious to the other, as the only objective is to close in on the ball.

The realtime limit is unfortunate, but then the subtask of moving to
the ball should be straightforward for NEAT - depending on how the
agent moves around I suppose.



> Every 100ms (once again, a realtime server limitation) for each of the networks we set
> inputs and get outputs and perform the decided action.
> We repeat the above NumActions times in EvalPop summing the fitness from each trial.
>
> Now for the questions:
> 1. On each subsequent call to EvalPop, should we reset the positions (random positions
> far from ball) and stats of the networks.

Yeh I think you need some degree of randomness in there otherwise you
will probably just find a solution that only deals with attacking the
ball from a certain angle or some other limited subset of possible
scenarios. The prey capture experiment you mention actually tests each
genome 100(I think) times per evaluation, each from a different random
starting point, roughly equidistant from the prey.

I would suggest you need to activate for a number of timesteps until
(A) The ball is reached or (B) a max number of timesteps is reached.
You can then assign fitness as something like  (CONST_MAX_FITNESS -
distance - timesteps_took). The constant term in there is required
because SharpNeat can only maximise a fitness score right now, not
minimise. So as the distance falls you want the fitness to go up.


> 3. Why does the GenomeList.Count vary? I noticed the same thing in preycapture. On
> the 2nd call to eval pop the count will be 1 extra, and a few hundred gens later it reduced
> to 1 less than the specified count. How can I disable this?

It's a side effect of the fitness sharing technique in SharpNEAT -
each species is assigned a new size based on it's fitness in the last
generation. That new size is based on a species' proportion of the
total population size - and in calculating each species' size rounding
occurs. So if the allocation was 6.5 the species actually gets 7
genomes. Thus you can expect at maximum 1 extra genome per species (I
think). I suppose you could disable speciation by setting the target
species sizes to 0 (this might break the code but you can try it) and
also setting a high initial comparison threshold value.

Alternatively you could ignore any excess genomes by assigning them a
zero fitness. It means you will miss the occasional good genome, but
it's not the end of the world.

Good Luck,

Colin.
